webwork-tex.statement: Suppose \(\vec{F}(x,y) = (x + 5) \vec{i} + (6 y + 2) \vec{j}\). Use the fundamental theorem of line integrals to calculate the following. \leavevmode\\\relax \leavevmode\\\relax (a) The line integral of \(\vec{F}\) along the line segment \(C\) from the point \(P = (1,0)\) to the point \(Q = (3,1)\). \leavevmode\\\relax \(\displaystyle \int_C \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r}\) = \mbox{\parbox[t]{15ex}{\hrulefill}} \leavevmode\\\relax \leavevmode\\\relax (b) The line integral of \(\vec{F}\) along the triangle \(C\) from the origin to the point \(P = (1,0)\) to the point \(Q = (3,1)\) and back to the origin. \leavevmode\\\relax \(\displaystyle \int_C \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r}\) = \mbox{\parbox[t]{15ex}{\hrulefill}}
